message:
Hello Geeks,
I faced a statistical/probability term in data science field which i cant find its  mean, the term is "log bilinear".
i know what is exactly meant by log linear which described nicely here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Log-linear_model
and here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Log-linear_analysis
also i found a question here with no  real answer   http://www.quora.com/What-is-a-log-bilinear-model
and also this http://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/157136/log-linear-vs-log-bilinear

 Geeks help make it clear to me ...thanks in advance
story: Ibrahim Zaki shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: Log-linear model - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
caption: en.wikipedia.org
description: A log-linear model is a mathematical model that takes the form of a function whose logarithm is a linear combination of the parameters of the model, which makes it possible to apply (possibly multivariate) linear regression. That is, it has the general form

data.message: I know nothing about Data Science, but in graphics/rendering bilinear is just linear on two axis instead of one (eg: bilinear interpolation is on  4 values on the x-axis and y-axis, while linear interpolation just happens on two values on one axis). Maybe something similar might be going on in data science, and maybe not :D
